triplet_3280_question.question: What is your opinion on tipping, and if given the chance, how would you improve or change the current tipping system? Please answer briefly in 2–3 sentences.
triplet_3280_question.text:
[Question]

What is your opinion on tipping, and if given the chance, how would you improve or change the current tipping system?
triplet_3280_question.displayed_text:
[Question]

What is your opinion on tipping, and if given the chance, how would you improve or change the current tipping system?

triplet_3280_rating.question: What is your opinion on tipping, and if given the chance, how would you improve or change the current tipping system? Please answer briefly in 2–3 sentences.
triplet_3280_rating.text:
Below is a summary of people's opinions on the issue.

Overall summary of the comments:

  • Sentiment: Most commenters view tipping culture as out of control and overly pressurized, especially with tablet prompts and requests in counter-service or pickup contexts. Many still tip regularly but dislike feeling obligated or being asked before service is delivered.

  • Pay and responsibility: A strong theme is that employers should pay a fair, livable base wage (at least minimum wage for tipped workers), so tips become a true bonus rather than a necessity. Many would abolish tipping entirely or replace it with higher menu prices or a built-in service charge. Some prefer keeping tips but only as optional and tied to excellent service.

  • Where tipping is appropriate: Broad agreement that tipping should primarily apply to full-service restaurants and delivery. Many oppose tipping for simple transactions (coffee, pickup, retail counters) or when customers serve themselves.

  • How to improve the system:

  • Reduce pressure and manipulation: make “no tip” easy to find, don’t prompt before service, and avoid default high suggested percentages.
  • Tie tips to service quality and make them clearly optional.
  • Consider alternatives: integrate service charges (e.g., 10%) into bills with tips optional; raise wages and eliminate tipping; adopt European/Japanese-style norms; limit who is tipped; reduce or remove taxes on tips; employer contributions or matching to stabilize income.

  • Clarify norms: limit tipping requests to contexts with clear, provided service; potentially reserve tipping for complex orders; reduce suggested tip rates; present less intrusive prompts.

  • Minority/pro-tipping views: A smaller share strongly supports tipping as an incentive, sometimes advocating high or even mandatory tips (e.g., 20–30%) unless wages meet a threshold. A few propose standardizing tips (fixed dollar amounts) or expanding tipping as a general gesture of appreciation.

  • Common ground: Tips, if used, should reward good service rather than compensate for low wages; customers want transparency, choice, and less social pressure; and workers should have predictable, fair income without relying on customer generosity.

triplet_3280_comparison.question: What is your opinion on tipping, and if given the chance, how would you improve or change the current tipping system? Please answer briefly in 2–3 sentences.
triplet_3280_comparison.text:
Two summaries of opinions are shown below. Read carefully and answer according to your prior opinion. Both are scrollable.

Summary A

Overall summary of the comments:

  • Sentiment: Most commenters view tipping culture as out of control and overly pressurized, especially with tablet prompts and requests in counter-service or pickup contexts. Many still tip regularly but dislike feeling obligated or being asked before service is delivered.

  • Pay and responsibility: A strong theme is that employers should pay a fair, livable base wage (at least minimum wage for tipped workers), so tips become a true bonus rather than a necessity. Many would abolish tipping entirely or replace it with higher menu prices or a built-in service charge. Some prefer keeping tips but only as optional and tied to excellent service.

  • Where tipping is appropriate: Broad agreement that tipping should primarily apply to full-service restaurants and delivery. Many oppose tipping for simple transactions (coffee, pickup, retail counters) or when customers serve themselves.

  • How to improve the system:

  • Reduce pressure and manipulation: make “no tip” easy to find, don’t prompt before service, and avoid default high suggested percentages.
  • Tie tips to service quality and make them clearly optional.
  • Consider alternatives: integrate service charges (e.g., 10%) into bills with tips optional; raise wages and eliminate tipping; adopt European/Japanese-style norms; limit who is tipped; reduce or remove taxes on tips; employer contributions or matching to stabilize income.

  • Clarify norms: limit tipping requests to contexts with clear, provided service; potentially reserve tipping for complex orders; reduce suggested tip rates; present less intrusive prompts.

  • Minority/pro-tipping views: A smaller share strongly supports tipping as an incentive, sometimes advocating high or even mandatory tips (e.g., 20–30%) unless wages meet a threshold. A few propose standardizing tips (fixed dollar amounts) or expanding tipping as a general gesture of appreciation.

  • Common ground: Tips, if used, should reward good service rather than compensate for low wages; customers want transparency, choice, and less social pressure; and workers should have predictable, fair income without relying on customer generosity.

Summary B

Overall summary of the comments: - Strong preference for making tipping voluntary rather than expected or mandatory, with tips tied to quality of service. - Widespread frustration with “tip creep” and pressure from point-of-sale prompts, especially for transactions with minimal or no service. - Broad agreement that employers should pay a livable base wage so workers do not have to rely on tips. - Recognition that tipping benefits workers, but customers can feel financially strained or guilted into tipping. - Suggested improvements include: eliminating mandatory tips, providing tangible acknowledgments for tips (e.g., thank-you notes or coupons), and allowing customers to tip what they can afford. - A minority view favors reframing tipping norms—either using fixed dollar amounts instead of percentages or encouraging higher standard tip amounts, particularly on low bills.

Overall summary of the comments:

- Widespread frustration with “tip creep” and pressure from point-of-sale prompts, especially for transactions with minimal or no service.
- Broad agreement that employers should pay a livable base wage so workers do not have to rely on tips.
- Recognition that tipping benefits workers, but customers can feel financially strained or guilted into tipping.
- Suggested improvements include: eliminating mandatory tips, providing tangible acknowledgments for tips (e.g., thank-you notes or coupons), and allowing customers to tip what they can afford.
- A minority view favors reframing tipping norms—either using fixed dollar amounts instead of percentages or encouraging higher standard tip amounts, particularly on low bills.
